1.text: It‚Äôs your last year in high school - a pivotal point in your life - and it‚Äôs time to make some tough decisions. It‚Äôs time to decide which university programs to apply to!

1.1.text: You truly enjoy Visual Arts, are quite talented, and could see yourself being very happy as an artist. However, you realize it is not the best degree for employment so you're also considering Computer Science. You heard there is good job security and you think you are decent at it.

1.2.speaker: Best Friend
1.2.text: Which program did you apply to?

options: Visual Arts at WCAD University
Computer Science at Materloo University
2.text: Which program did you choose to apply to?

2.1.speaker: Best Friend
2.1.text: Don‚Äôt forget about me when you‚Äôre famous! üòõ

2.2.speaker: Best Friend
2.2.text: Don‚Äôt forget about me when you‚Äôre rich! üòõ

3.text: You‚Äôve been really struggling financially ever since you started university because your parents don‚Äôt support your decision to become an artist. There‚Äôs an art contest for students happening at your local gallery and the prize is a huge scholarship that‚Äôll really help you out. You won‚Äôt have to worry about making rent every month! Plus, your art will be shown at the local gallery - that‚Äôll be great for your career!

4.text: You want to enter a piece into the contest, but the thing is, you‚Äôre not a very good artist since you just started studying art seriously. The prompt sounds impossible for you to paint! It's... "a longhaired daschund". But, your friend recently showed you an AI art generator called WALLE-2 that you could use to make some impressive art. All you have to do is enter the prompt into the tool! You would feel guilty using it though... do you deserve to call it your art?
4.context: WALLE-2 is based on DALLE-2, OpenAI's popular (but controversial) AI image generating system.

options: Pass off AI art as your own
Draw your own art
5.text: What will you enter into the art fair?

6.text: You decide to generate a hyperrealistic piece using WALLE-2. It took you a couple of minutes to tune the adjectives to produce something you liked, but it looks amazing! You get it printed on a canvas immediately and submit it to the gallery without mentioning the AI component.

7.text: Congratulations! You won the contest! Everyone LOVES your art and can‚Äôt stop talking about it! It must‚Äôve taken you years to develop your skills, and you can now go to university stress free. However, you‚Äôre starting to feel guility about passing off the AI generated art as your own.

options: Confess to the judges
Hell no! Take the money and run
8.text: Do you confess to the judges?

9.text: Everyone is shocked by the revelation and the judges reconvene to discuss what should be done given this new information.

10.text: After some deliberation, it‚Äôs revealed that you still won! Congratulations! The response is polarizing. Some people are angry at you, calling you a fraud and some people think you deserve the prize. "You‚Äôre a fraud! You didn‚Äôt make this!‚Äù, someone from the crowd screams.

options: ‚ÄúI made the prompt, everything came from my brain. AI is just a tool - like a paint brush!‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs gonna happen sooner or later, suck it up!‚Äù
11.context: The contestant who won the art competition with an AI-generated piece has defended his choice in an interview: bit.ly/3F5YvK5

12.text: You go congratulate the 2nd place winner, Luca, and end up befriending him. You tell him how amazing his art is and find out that he will be attending the same university as you are! You now get to go to university on a scholarship! No need to stress about money anymore!

13.text: You try your best in art school, but you just don‚Äôt have enough skill to keep up. Your grades begin to fall and you need to do something about it. You want to use AI to generate some art for you  - it‚Äôs the only way to not flunk out.

options: Yes
No
14.text: Do you use AI art to cheat on your assignments?

15.text: After a grueling 4 years, you‚Äôve graduated! You‚Äôve relied heavily on AI to pass your classes but now you‚Äôre done. Your friend Luca graduates with you as well. Luca gets a job in graphic design in order to make ends meet, while you‚Äôre able to do freelance given the reputation you‚Äôve accrued over the years.

16.text: A billionaire approaches you about a possible commission. They want a piece in a similar style for their house and are offering you 2 million dollars! You try using the generators but it‚Äôs not giving you the right results. You realise that putting some of Luca‚Äôs art into the algorithm will give the perfect result. The art you plug in technically isn‚Äôt his because he made it for a company - so it should be ok, right? Still, you feel guilty. But 2 million dollars will change your life.

options: Use it, it‚Äôs not technically his art.
Don‚Äôt do it. Just use the results you have already
17.text: Do you feed in Luca‚Äôs art to WALLE-2 and pass it off as your own work?

18.text: This puts you on the map. The billionaire shares your piece online and it gets well recieved. People are reposting and reposting - it‚Äôs become viral. Luca sees the art and is shocked - it‚Äôs in his exact style. He realizes that you‚Äôve been using AI art this whole time and confronts you about it.

18.1.speaker: Luca
18.1.text: How could you steal my style and profit off of my hard work? I trusted you!

options: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not technically your art - I made the prompt so it‚Äôs mine!‚Äù
‚ÄúSure it‚Äôs your style, but you can‚Äôt prevent me from using it. It‚Äôs a style, not your property!‚Äù
19.text: How do you respond to Luca?

20.text: You are now a world-renowed artist. You‚Äôve done very well for yourself, but you feel like a fraud knowing that you‚Äôve become successful off of working for 3 minutes on each piece, while your friend Luca spends hours upon hours only to be less successful than you.

21.text: The billionaire isn‚Äôt impressed with your work at all and only gives you a small portion of the money. This hurts your career and no one wants to work with you anymore. No more commissions come in, and you‚Äôre struggling to make ends meet. You don‚Äôt know what to do because your skills are now limited to that of using AI art generators.

22.text: Your hard work almost paid off, and you placed second. You overhear the winner bragging about using an AI image generator to create their submission. You feel frustrated. If you used AI, maybe you would‚Äôve won. Seems like having merit doesn‚Äôt pay off!
22.context: In August 2022, Colorado State Fair's fine arts competition judges awarded first place to a contestant who entered a fully AI-generated piece: nyti.ms/3VR0IA1.

options: Yes
No
23.text: Should you just start doing AI art?

24.text: Your art gets better and better as you practice more and more. You‚Äôre struggling to make ends meet, but that‚Äôs the artist lifestyle - right?

options: Commissions for companies
Freelance, online work
25.text: How do you want to make your money?

26.text: You begin doing comissions for a myriad of companies. The money you get from this is pretty good! As you browse the internet one day, you find that a comic book is being published, and you‚Äôre shocked to see that the style is incredibly similar to your own. How did this happen?
26.context: With the recent popularity surrounding AI art generators, illustrators of all kinds are finding their work being used without their permission to generate new art in their exact style: bit.ly/3VLYKRC

options: Contact the author and ask
Go on Fwitter and expose the author
27.text: What do you do in response?

28.text: The author is delighted you reached out - they‚Äôre a big fan! They put your art that they found online into an AI art generator to mirror your style. They see nothing wrong with what they‚Äôve done.
28.context: With the recent popularity surrounding AI art generators, illustrators of all kinds are finding their work being used without their permission to generate new art in their exact style: bit.ly/3VLYKRC

options: ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt give you permission to use my work‚Äù
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre profiting off of my work, I deserve a share‚Äù
29.text: How do you respond to them?

30.text: The author says that they used work they found on other websites and later traced it back to you as the artist. Because of this, it wasn‚Äôt really your work that they took. You realise that because these pieces were comissions, they aren‚Äôt yours to give permission to. There‚Äôs nothing you can do about this, unless the company you did the comission for wants to, which of course they don‚Äôt.
30.context: With the recent popularity surrounding AI art generators, illustrators of all kinds are finding their work being used without their permission to generate new art in their exact style: bit.ly/3VLYKRC

options: Sue them, they stole your style regardless
Welp, I guess there‚Äôs nothing I can do...
31.text: What do you do about your stolen style?

32.text: In an attempt to fight back, the author copyrights the comic book and is successful. They have successfully copyrighted the comic that uses your style. You lost. There‚Äôs nothing you can do, just go back to comissioning pieces, and accept that your art is vulnerable to being taken again. All the time you‚Äôve spent honing your unique style didn‚Äôt matter, because now it‚Äôs for the public to use.
32.context: In the first successful case of its kind, an artist has successfully copyrighted a comic book fully generated using AI art: bit.ly/3B9egz2.

33.text: You‚Äôve worked your way up to be a great artist, with an amazing and unique style. The style you‚Äôve developed over the years is now profitable, but none of the money is going into your pockets. All the time you‚Äôve spent honing your unique style didn‚Äôt matter, because now it‚Äôs for the public to use. Hell, there‚Äôs a comic book out there using your style and you‚Äôre getting none of it. There‚Äôs nothing you can do, just go back to comission pieces, and accept that your art is vulnerable to being taken again.
33.context: With the recent popularity surrounding AI art generators, illustrators of all kinds are finding their work being used without their permission to generate new art in their exact style: bit.ly/3VLYKRC

34.text: The author disagrees, saying that they aren‚Äôt technically using your work. Rather, it‚Äôs new images that came from their mind. You realise that because these pieces were comissions, they aren‚Äôt yours to give permission to. So there‚Äôs nothing you can do about this, unless the company you did the comission for wants to - which of course they don‚Äôt.

35.text: You accumulate quite the support online. A lot of people understand your frustration - how could someone profit off of your style?  The author comes out and states that they were simply inspired by your art that they found online. It‚Äôs entirely new art, so they didn‚Äôt do anything wrong. You realise that because these pieces were comissions, they aren‚Äôt yours to give permission to. There‚Äôs nothing you can do about this, unless the company you did the comission for wants to - which of course they don‚Äôt.

options: Sue them, they stole your style regardless
Welp, I guess there‚Äôs nothing I can do...
36.text: What do you do about your stolen style?

37.text: You threaten to sue, and media attention begins to grow. Many people are on your side - they believe your style was stolen by the author. But, many others believe that you have no grounds to sue; a style isn‚Äôt something you own. In an attempt to fight back, the author copyrights the comic book and is successful. They have successfully copyrighted the comic that uses your style. You lost. There‚Äôs nothing you can do, just go back to comissioning pieces, and accept that your art is vulnerable to being taken again. All the time you‚Äôve spent honing your unique style didn‚Äôt matter, because now it‚Äôs for the public to use.
37.context: Law experts predict an incoming "wave of litigation" from artists: bit.ly/3Uxkpvt. And, in the first case of its kind, an artist has successfully copyrighted a comic book fully generated using AI art: bit.ly/3B9egz2.

38.text: You‚Äôve worked your way up to be a great artist, with an amazing and unique style. The style you‚Äôve developed over the years is now profitable, but none of the money is going into your pockets. All the time you‚Äôve spent honing your unique style didn‚Äôt matter, because now it‚Äôs for the public to use. Hell, there‚Äôs a comic book out there using your style and you‚Äôre getting none of the recognition. There‚Äôs nothing you can do, just go back to comission pieces, and accept that your art is vulnerable to being taken again.
38.context: Experts and professional artists alike are concerned about the effect that AI art generators will have on mid-career artists that have finally found their niche: bit.ly/3P4OMIK

39.text: You begin sharing your art online with lukewarm success. You keep posting and hoping that at some point your art will gain traction. A few months have passed, but still, nothing. As you browse the internet one day, you find art pieces that look very similar to your style have gotten very popular. They have tens of thousands reposts, and these accounts are accruing thousands in commission profits. Upon further inspection, you find that the people have been using AI art to generate content in your style. Particularly, using your name in the prompt.

options: Ignore it, there‚Äôs nothing that can be done. Plus I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs good publicity for me!
Contact a journalist to do a story on this
40.text: What do you do about it?

41.text: You ignore the issue and continue with your work. You continue to churn out beautiful pieces of art and post them on your social media pages. However, you notice that your views and engagment has gone down immensely. You try to find out why this is by searching up your own name. And you find large amounts of art that look like yours, but aren‚Äôt made by you. Your style is being saturated by AI art.
41.context: Experts and professional artists alike are concerned about the effect that AI art generators will have on mid-career artists that have finally found their niche: bit.ly/3P4OMIK

42.text: A popular newspaper picks up your story, hoping to cash in on the hype of AI art. They publish a story about the accounts that have stolen your style, and how they‚Äôve affected your career. In the next few days, you have hundreds of artists and interested customers messaging you in support, and commissioning you. In the next few months though, you notice that while the original copycat accounts have lost many of their followers, new ones with thousands of followers pop up every week. You can‚Äôt help but feel like the issue will never go away.
42.context: A blog post was published reporting on a working artist having her art style imitated with AI generators, and then released under open licenses: bit.ly/3uph1IA

43.text: After 4 long years, graduation approaches and you are ready to get out there and start making money! After going through tons of new grad applications you wait to hear back.

doc: Our team had a wonderful time interviewing with you! We are so excited to extend an offer for you to join the family at Enviro üå±!!
We look forward to providing you with some amazing opportunities to grow with us during your early career.
Wishing you the best and look forward to hearing back,
Congratulations! We are looking forward to having you join Fwitter as a new grad software engineeer.
Please reply to confirm and we can proceed with next steps.

43.4.text: You know that Enviro is a small non-profit that works to track the carbon footprint of companies to help them become more sustainable.

43.5.text: Fwitter on the other hand, is a large social media company, you don't really use it, but all your friends do.

options: Enviro, the small non-profit looking to help make the world more sustainable through carbon footprint tracking.
Fwitter, a social media platform for voicing your ideas.
43.6.text: Thankful and excited for your career, you reply to

44.text: A few weeks pass by as you onboard onto Fwitter's engineering team. You're excited by the opportunity for impact at Fwitter, and can't wait to take on exciting projects.
